issue.title: Playwright tests/behaves differently when running in parallel [BUG]
issue.body:
## Describe the bug
- Running my tests using multiple workers, they pass
- Running tests on GitHub actions using a single worker, they fail

## example
I narrowed down the problem, it has to do with async and/or computational heavy actions that get triggered by a mouse interaction. Basically:
- listens to the mouse events
- do something intensive or async
- go a few hoops back and store the event value
- from the test grab the stored value in the assertion

This will pass (most of the time, not always) on your machine if you have a good one but fail (most of the time) on the remote test

- [See example repo: https://github.com/ThibaultJanBeyer/playwright-race-condition](https://github.com/ThibaultJanBeyer/playwright-race-condition)

## ideas
- There could be an option that one mouse interaction to another mouse interaction only happens when the event loop is clear
  - I believe this is done with the`requestIdleCallback`, which unfortunately is [not (yet) supported by safari](https://caniuse.com/requestidlecallback)

I’ll try out the idea listed above, but if you have any other ideas, happy to hear them!

## Context:
- Playwright Version: 1.27.1
- Operating System: MacOs 13.0 (22A380)
- Node.js version: 14.18.2
- Browser: All

**Moar Context**
Hello 👋 , I am working on a library called ([dragselect](https://github.com/ThibaultJanBeyer/DragSelect/)) that does listen for mouse interaction, calculates mouse positions and elements in between, and a lot more to provide a selection and drag and drop functionality. I have no issues testing it with Puppeteer, today, however, I wanted to switch to playwright because it is faster, supposedly non-flaky, and I thought would integrate better with GitHub-actions and VSCode. So I tried it out but seems like it is flakier than puppeteer for my use case.

payload.description: reproducing a race condition issue
reproducing a race condition issue

issue.title: Testing/playwright
issue.body: using playwright instead of puppeteer for functional testing. This should improve reliability and also allows testing all 3 major browsers

comment.body: ok well well the sad part here is that these tests using playwright seem to be even more flaky than puppeteer :/

commits.message: use cli instead of microsoft action

pull_request.title: Add support for pointerEvents
pull_request.body:
Hi, thanks for this great library. I'm now preparing to use DragSelect for implementing [Google Blockly](https://github.com/google/blockly)'s [multiselection project](https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/programs/2022/projects/9wF06HWE). However, DragSelect can't work on Blockly as of now, Google Blockly uses the pointerEvents:

https://github.com/google/blockly/blob/24a808d54eef1711801ff3b7e6082409a8a78666/core/browser_events.js#L95-L100
https://github.com/google/blockly/blob/master/core/touch.js#L58-L69

So this PR makes DragSelect also listen to the pointerEvents so that it can work for the Blockly. It would be great if this PR can get merged and a new release can be drafted for this. Thank you!

So this PR makes DragSelect also listen to the pointerEvents so that it can work for the Blockly. It would be great if this PR can get merged and a new release can be drafted for this. Thank you!

pull_request.title: Features/dropzones #115
pull_request.body:
This PR Adds the concept of "dropzones"!
This will help you with your drag-and-drop requirements:

- Select multiple elements and drop them in the corresponding zone
- Find the target dropZone and corresponding elements in the response
- Get elements inside the zone
- Get elements previously dropped into the zone

Visual Example:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12467511/199550933-c88489d8-d43d-4929-8aa0-9e9d9eb71328.mp4

💥 what a banger! 💥

issue.title: Link for Postgres example seems wrong
issue.body:
Dear team, in the readme.md the link to the Postgres example is just redirecting to the express-4 one which is written using mongodb:

```
Postgres
[Tutorial](http://mherman.org/blog/2015/01/31/local-authentication-with-passport-and-express-4/) / [working example](https://github.com/mjhea0/passport-local-express4)
```

I don’t know which one would be the correct link, otherwise, this would have been a PR.
Cheers
